Package: com.jnorthr

[Groovy] Class H2

    • com.jnorthr.H2

    • Represents an abstraction against an instance of the H2 in-memory database. Used to persist and order info. within a single table.

      • Properties Summary

          Properties 
          Type Name and description
          java.lang.String  dbname
          Name of the H2 database to be established

          An instance of the sql statement processor

          java.lang.String  tablename
          Name of the table to be established within this H2 database

      • Property Detail

        • java.lang.String dbname

          Name of the H2 database to be established

        • groovy.sql.Sql sql

          An instance of the sql statement processor

        • boolean tableOpen

          A flag set true after the first use of the tablename. Used to avoid issues where tablename is changed after database already in use.

        • java.lang.String tablename

          Name of the table to be established within this H2 database

      • Constructor Detail

        • H2()

          Creates an instance of the H2 in-memory database. The database container name defaults to 'data'. The user.home location is included in the default database name.

        • H2(java.lang.String dbtable)

          Creates a specific instance of the H2 in-memory database with the given name. It creates an H2 database name from the String value given to the this constructor. The ~ tilde character is required to identify the user.home location of the declared database. An example database name of '~/fred' would create a temporary database named 'fred' in the user.home folder.

          Parameters:
          dbtable - - the name to be used for this instance of an H2 database

      • Method Detail

        • java.lang.Object add(java.lang.String cmd, java.util.Map map)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.execute(cmd,map). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql insert statement. Examples include several choices choices. For example: h2.add("insert into ${h2.tablename} values(:id, :value)", [id: 41, value: 'hello 41']) Any needed sql replacement parameters are provided with a map passed in as the second parm.

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql statement to be used against the currently open table
          map - sql replacement parameters in the form of [id:76] as Map
          Returns:
          count of affected rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object get(java.lang.String cmd)

          Executes the sql select statement using sql.rows(cmd). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql select statement. Examples include 'where' and 'order by' choices. For example: h2.get("select * from ${h2.tablename} where id > 43 order by value")

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql statement to be used against the currently open table
          Returns:
          array of matching rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object get(java.lang.String cmd, java.util.Map map, groovy.lang.Closure logic)

          Executes the sql select statement using sql.rows(cmd,map,closure) passing each selected row to the provided closure logic. The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql select statement. Examples include 'where' and 'order by' choices. For example: h2.get("select * from ${h2.tablename} where id > ?1.id order by value",[id:24],{e-> println e.id; }) Processing logic to be applied to each row is declared in a named or anonymous closure

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql statement to be used against the currently open table
          map - sql replacement parameters in the form of [id:76] as Map
          logic - named or anonymous closure to be applied to each row
          Returns:
          array of matching rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object get(java.lang.String cmd, groovy.lang.Closure logic)

          Executes the sql select statement using sql.rows(cmd,closure) passing each selected row to the provided closure logic. The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql select statement. Examples include 'where' and 'order by' choices. For example: h2.get("select * from ${h2.tablename} where id > 47 order by value",{e-> }) Processing logic to be applied to each row is declared in a named or anonymous closure

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql statement to be used against the currently open table
          logic - named or anonymous closure to be applied to each row
          Returns:
          array of matching rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object get(java.lang.String cmd, java.util.Map map)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.rows(cmd,map). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql select statement. Examples include 'where' and 'order by' choices. For example: h2.get("select * from ${h2.tablename} where id > ?1.id order by value",[id:44]) Any needed sql replacement parameters are provided with a map passed in as the second parm.

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql statement to be used against the currently open table
          map - sql replacement parameters in the form of [id:76] as Map
          Returns:
          array of matching rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object get(java.lang.String cmd, java.util.Map map1, java.util.Map map2)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.rows(cmd,map,map). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql select statement. Examples include 'where' and 'order by' choices. For example: h2.get("select * from ${h2.tablename} where id > 0 order by value") Any needed sql replacement parameters are provided with maps passed in as the second and third parms.

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql statement to be used against the currently open table
          map - sql replacement parameters in the form of [id:76] as Map
          map - sql replacement parameters in the form of [value:'Fred'] as Map
          Returns:
          array of matching rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object insert(java.lang.String cmd)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.executeInsert(cmd). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql statement. Examples include most update choices. For example: "insert into test set value='Frank' where id=11" Any needed sql replacement parameters are provided with a map passed in as the second parm.

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql executeInsert statement to be used against the currently open table
          Returns:
          id's of inserted rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object insert(java.lang.String cmd, java.util.Map map)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.executeInsert(cmd,map). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql insert statement. Examples include most update choices. For example: h2.insert("insert into ${h2.tablename} values(:id, :value)", [id: 41, value: 'hello 41']) Any needed sql replacement parameters are provided with a map passed in as the second parm.

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql update statement to be used against the currently open table
          map - sql replacement parameters in the form of [id:76] as Map
          Returns:
          id's of inserted rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object logmsg(java.lang.String method, java.lang.String sqlcmd, java.lang.String cmd, boolean flag)

        • static void main(java.lang.String[] args)

          Method to run class tests.

          Parameters:
          args - Value is string array - possibly empty - of command-line values.
          Returns:
          void

        • java.lang.Object put(java.lang.String cmd, java.util.Map map)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.execute(cmd,map). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql insert statement. Examples include most update choices. For example: h2.put("insert into ${h2.tablename} values(:id, :value)", [id: 41, value: 'hello 41']) Any needed sql replacement parameters are provided with a map passed in as the second parm.

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql statement to be used against the currently open table
          map - sql replacement parameters in the form of [id:76] as Map
          Returns:
          count of affected rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object run(java.lang.String cmd)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.execute(cmd). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql statement. Examples include most DDL choices. For example: "create table if not exists test (id int, value char)"

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql statement to be executed against the currently open table
          Returns:
          count of affected rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object run(java.lang.String cmd, java.util.Map map)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.execute(cmd,map). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql statement. Examples include most DDL choices. For example: h2.run("delete from ${h2.tablename} where id > ?1.id",[id:31])

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql statement to be executed against the currently open table
          map - sql replacement parameters in the form of [id:78] as Map
          Returns:
          count of affected rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object setPaging(int startAt, int howMany)

          Establish values for multi-row paging algorithm. This is typically for an sql select stmt.

          throws:
          IOException when attempt is made to change tablename but database is already open and table is in use
          Parameters:
          int - startAt a base-1 value of the number of the row as the first row to be taken from a multi-row select
          int - howMany a value of the maximum number of the rows to be returned beginning from the 'startAt' row.
          Returns:
          void

        • java.lang.Object setTableName(java.lang.String newtablename)

          Returns tablename for submitted sql statements. The cmd argument must be a valid H2 name. For example: h2.setTableName("fred")

          throws:
          IOException when attempt is made to change tablename but database is already open and table is in use
          Parameters:
          newtablename - the table name to be used against the currently unopened database
          Returns:
          tablename to be used by database if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object update(java.lang.String cmd)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.executeUpdate(cmd). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql statement. Examples include most update choices. For example: "update test set value='Fred' where id=1" Any needed parameters are declared within the command.

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql update statement to be used against the currently open table
          Returns:
          count of affected rows if the command was successful

        • java.lang.Object update(java.lang.String cmd, java.util.Map map)

          Executes the submitted sql statement using sql.executeUpdate(cmd,map). The cmd argument must be a valid H2 sql statement. Examples include most update choices. For example: "update test set value='Frank' where id=11" Any needed sql replacement parameters are provided with a map passed in as the second parm.

          Parameters:
          cmd - the sql update statement to be used against the currently open table
          map - sql replacement parameters in the form of [id:76] as Map
          Returns:
          count of affected rows if the command was successful
